title: A Framework to Quantify Approximate Simulation on Graph Data

sections.related work:
Simulation and Its Variants.
In this paper, we focused on four simulation variants: simple simulation  , bisimulation , degree-preserving simulation  and bijective simulation. The original definition of simulation  only considered out-neighbors, but Ma et al.â€™s redefinition in 2011  takes in-neighbors into account and hence is the definition we used. Reverting to the original definition is as easy as setting wâˆ’=0superscriptğ‘¤0w^{-}=0 in our framework. Additionally, we discussed a variant of approximate bisimulation, namely kğ‘˜k-bisimulation 0 1 2 0, and investigated its relation to our framework (SectionÂ 4.3). There are other variants that have not yet included in the framework, including bounded simulation  and weak simulation . These variants consider the kğ‘˜k-hop neighbors (kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1) in addition to the immediate neighbors. As an interesting future work, we will study to incorporate them in our framework. There are also some algorithms that aim to compute simulation (variants) efficiently and effectively, e.g., a hash-based algorithm in 0, external-memory algorithms in  2, a distributed algorithm in 1 and a partition refinement algorithm in 8. However, all these algorithms compute the â€œyes-or-noâ€ simulation (or its variant) and cannot provide fractional scores as proposed in this paper. Node Similarity Measures.  We have shown that ğ–¥ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–»ğ—ƒsubscriptğ–¥ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–»ğ—ƒ{\mathsf{FSim}}_{{\mathsf{bj}}} is qualified for node similarity measurement. Thus, we review node similarity measures on labeled graphs. ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–±ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–±ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„\mathsf{SimRank} 8 and ğ–±ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–±ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†\mathsf{RoleSim} 9 are two representative measures, and their relations to our ğ–¥ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Ï‡subscriptğ–¥ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğœ’{\mathsf{FSim}}_{\chi} have been discussed in SectionÂ 4.3. As these two measures are less effective in computing node similarity on labeled graphs 3 1, similarity measures 3 9 1 2 were proposed. ğ–¯ğ–ºğ—ğ—ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–¯ğ–ºğ—ğ—ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†\mathsf{PathSim} 1, for instance, uses a ratio of meta-paths connecting two nodes as the measure. ğ–©ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–©ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†\mathsf{JoinSim} 2 is similar to ğ–¯ğ–ºğ—ğ—ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–¯ğ–ºğ—ğ—ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†\mathsf{PathSim}, but it satisfies the triangle inequality. ğ—‡ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–¦ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—†ğ—‡ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–¦ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—†\mathsf{nSimGram} 3 computes node similarity based on q-grams instead of meta-paths to capture more topology information. Note that these measures cannot substitute our work as their scores are not related to simulation and thus are not suitable to quantify the extent of simulation. Similarity-based Applications. There are a number of works on pattern matching and graph alignment that are based on node similarity techniques. These works may differ in measuring node similarities. Specifically, ğ–¨ğ—Œğ—ˆğ–±ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğ–¨ğ—Œğ—ˆğ–±ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„\mathsf{IsoRank} 3 computes the similarity between two nodes based on an weighted average of their neighborsâ€™ scores. ğ–­ğ–¾ğ–¬ğ–ºğ–­ğ–¾ğ–¬ğ–º\mathsf{NeMa} 4 defines a vector that encodes the neighborhood information for each node. The distance between two nodes is then computed from these vectors. ğ–­ğ– ğ–¦ğ– ğ–­ğ– ğ–¦ğ– \mathsf{NAGA} 5 leverages statistical significance through chi-square measure to compute node similarity. ğ–±ğ–¤ğ–¦ğ– ğ–«ğ–±ğ–¤ğ–¦ğ– ğ–«\mathsf{REGAL} 0 measures the similarity of two nodes by taking the information of kğ‘˜k-hop neighbors into account. ğ–¥ğ–¨ğ–±ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–¨ğ–±ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{FIRST} 1 and ğ–¥ğ–¨ğ–­ğ– ğ–«ğ–¥ğ–¨ğ–­ğ– ğ–«\mathsf{FINAL} 6 use a Sylvester equation to compute similarities, which encodes structural consistency and attribute consistency of two networks. For similar reasons, these works are also not suitable to quantify the degree of simulation.
